comments.commentBody: Amy, I don't know how to say anything after reading your incredibly moving love letter, except: thank you.  Jason has an amazing wife.

Uber and the like tapped into a need that wasn't met - for flexible, accessible, affordable car service. Existing regulations essentially sustained a stultified, self-protective monopoly that wasn't working for many potential customers.

Like all profit driven corporations, Uber will use whatever it can to gain an upper hand - over its drivers, governments and customers. tracking individuals to be able to deny them service - or to deny the opportunity to inspect operations -highly discriminatory.

Perhaps it is the drivers - if they are not too desperate and beholden - who have to be the first to come together to increase their power vis a vis their de facto employer.

Modern regulations are needed - as a protection to driver and customers, but also to develop some way of having Uber contribute to local taxes - you know, because the infrastructure isn't free.

If you think government regulations would actually serve "as a protection to driver and customers", I've got some real estate in Florida to sell you. These "government regulations" is what created the corrupt and poorly serving taxi industry (in which cities create artificial shortages to boost prices, provide those who support--er donate to--the politicians exclusive medallions). This causes difficulty for riders to find cabs.
Also, the drivers for UberX already pay taxes (including gasoline taxes) to pay for the infrastructure they use, so that's already taken care of.
Lastly, the contractors driving for Uber are given a flexible work option--totally at their choice--to earn money when they otherwise would not. In many foreign countries (like Brazil for instance), it has restored dignity to those who found themselves unemployed for lengthy periods.
Bravo and thank you, Uber!

"Perhaps it is the drivers - if they are not too desperate and beholden - who have to be the first to come together to increase their power vis a vis their de facto employer."

By doing what? Come together to increase their power vis a vis their de facto employer by organizing a union? Capitalism is anti-union.
Exactly! The only thing that Uber should have to do is to offshore its before-tax profit.

Amy,

May you live forever in the circle of heaven.

Ira

Dear Amy,

Thank you for reminding me exactly what true love is, it does exist. I wish you many more smiley faces, I believe they will surround you forever! I admire your strength and most of all, the amazing love you are showing your husband.

Oh my God. Amy this is so inspiring and beautifuly writin. I live who you are. You are pure Love. I honer you for the human being you are. You depicted Jason as the perfect man on the planet and he is who he is because of you. You are so powerful and evolved and I'm sure that's why it is time for you to leave the physical realm. I wish I could have a Jason in my life. I wish you the easiest transition as you pass. Sending you love and light. May you do everything you desire before you leave your body. Regards
Best to your family and I wish peace and patience for your family and Jason. I would have liked bed to meet you and Jason both and get to know you.

Love

Ava Kashani
I want to marry her.  He sounds like an amazing man...but, she magnetized him towards her.  I want to love this way in my life.

Sending you a lot of love and peace. I don't know what it is like to face cancer, but it sounds like you are very loved, with a happy family and amazing work. I am wishing you every ounce of peace in this process. Hugs from afar.
You must be gone now. Too soon for your beloved husband to dream of another person in  his life.
Amy...I want to be more like you.  You are inspiring.

What is entirely apparent from reading your letter is that he is definitely lucky to have had you all these years as a couple sharing toegther as you have been is what makes a wonderful marriage. It feeds from the both of you and florishes from what you both brought to it together. He sounds like a great guy, and wjhile I have no interest in marrying him, it would be great knowing him, I'm sure. He will surely have plenty interested in getting to know him, but I'm sure he will feel it is no easy task to find someone to follow you in his life.. May your days together, however few they may be, be filled with many opportunities for you and him to just be. Peace.

As someone who got divorced after 20 years and thought of marriage as a great job that one dedicates their whole life to I am impressed by how much you have to say that is positive about your marriage. I clearly was not as smart as you or I would still be married. The joy you experienced is in both Jason and your kids and your appreciation of life deserves the only award possible and the one no one can grant - more life. What you have written is a mitzvah.

Uber is essentially a pirate operation. It employs loads of individuals (many of whom are suspect) who have a car but no other business expenses to compete with conventional taxi services which have a load of operational and regulatory costs. Voila their prices are lower and because of industry and regulatory pushback Uber has to employ all sorts of sleazy tactics to stay in business as is usual with all pirate operations. This quasi criminal culture seems endemic in the business judging by the other claims of sexual harassment and the personal behavior of is CEO.

What about easy-to-use mobile technology, customer convenience and clean, well maintained vehicles? When it comes to pirates, you the one parroting the bitter complaints of the entrenched taxi and limousine interests.
May you have MORE!!!

Awwww...you 2 sound like soul mates. God bless you both. I lost my husband to liver cancer last year. July 4th at 4:20am. His favorite holiday....& it was mine...not so much now.
Jason, I'm sorry for what you are about to go thru...it is a storm, one you won't soon forget or conquer. Let it change you, let it scar you, let it remind you of what is important in this life. Don't let it make you afraid to love again.
To your beautiful wife....I'm so sorry, so very sorry. Let your angels guide you, let your family & friends that have gone before you light your way....go in peace & gratitude in your heart. ❤
Amy! Just Amy.

I'm almost 50 years old and will get married this summer to the man I finally found after 35 years of looking. I don't know what I want to say to you, other than I'm so glad for you that it didn't take until you were 50 to find the love of your life. I'm so glad you had that time with him. You should have another 10,000+ days together, at the very least. I wish you both, and your families, a bottomless well of love and peace in the days ahead.

A love letter to your husband.
If I was a woman.
I wouldn't want to try to fill your shoes

Quote: Section §6103(f)(5) is a whistleblower exception to the general rule of nondisclosure... It permits disclosure of tax returns to one of the tax-writing committees by “any person who otherwise has or had access to any return or return information under this section” when that person believes that “such return or return information may relate to possible misconduct, maladministration, or taxpayer abuse.”

Can we pass this info around? Surely we can get it an authorized IRS employee.
